2.text: Of a truth I know it is so; but how can man be just with God?

3.text: If he shall choose to strive with him, he cannot answer him one thing of a thousand.

4.text: He is wise in heart and mighty in strength: who hath hardened himself against him, and had peace?

5.text: Who removeth mountains, and they know it not, when he overturneth them in his anger;

6.text: Who shaketh the earth out of its place, and the pillars thereof tremble;

7.text: Who commandeth the sun, and it riseth not, and he sealeth up the stars;

8.text: Who alone spreadeth out the heavens, and treadeth upon the high waves of the sea;

9.text: Who maketh the Bear, Orion, and the Pleiades, and the chambers of the south;

10.text: Who doeth great things past finding out, and wonders without number.

11.text: Lo, he goeth by me, and I see [him] not; and he passeth along, and I perceive him not.

12.text: Behold, he taketh away: who will hinder him? Who will say unto him, What doest thou?

13.text: +God withdraweth not his anger; the proud helpers stoop under him:

14.text: How much less shall I answer him, choose out my words [to strive] with him?

15.text: Whom, though I were righteous, [yet] would I not answer; I would make supplication to my judge.

16.text: If I had called, and he had answered me, I would not believe that he hearkened to my voice,â€”

17.text: He, who crusheth me with a tempest, and multiplieth my wounds without cause.

18.text: He suffereth me not to take my breath, for he filleth me with bitternesses.

19.text: Be it a question of strength, lo, [he is] strong; and be it of judgment, who will set me a time?

20.text: If I justified myself, mine own mouth would condemn me; were I perfect, he would prove me perverse.

21.text: Were I perfect, [yet] would I not know my soul: I would despise my life.

22.text: It is all one; therefore I said, he destroyeth the perfect and the wicked.

23.text: If the scourge kill suddenly, he mocketh at the trial of the innocent.

24.text: The earth is given over into the hand of the wicked [man]; he covereth the faces of its judges. If not, who then is it?

25.text: And my days are swifter than a runner: they flee away, they see no good.

26.text: They pass by like skiffs of reed; as an eagle that swoops upon the prey.

27.text: If I say, I will forget my complaint, I will leave off my [sad] countenance, and brighten up,

28.text: I am afraid of all my sorrows; I know that thou wilt not hold me innocent.

29.text: Be it that I am wicked, why then do I labour in vain?

30.text: If I washed myself with snow-water, and cleansed my hands in purity,

31.text: Then wouldest thou plunge me in the ditch, and mine own clothes would abhor me.

32.text: For he is not a man, as I am, that I should answer him; that we should come together in judgment.

33.text: There is not an umpire between us, who should lay his hand upon us both.

34.text: Let him take his rod away from me, and let not his terror make me afraid,

35.text: [Then] I will speak, and not fear him; but it is not so with me.
